title: Ampersand
content:
**[Indices](http://web.archive.org/web/20140305061247/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Indices) : [Terminology](http://web.archive.org/web/20140305061247/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Terminology) : Ampersand**

The ampersand is a punctuation character evolved from the Latin word _et_, meaning _and_. The visual evolution of the word et into a ligature and then into the common form we use today. Many contemporary typefaces offer alternate ampersands with the old form. See an article by [Max Caflisch](http://web.archive.org/web/20140305061247/http:/typophile.com/wiki/Max%20Caflisch) which offers some historical background and several typographic examples showing [the progression of the ampersand](http://web.archive.org/web/20140305061247/http:/www.adobe.com/type/topics/theampersand.html).
